texts.shortText: Distinctive dark-grey barnacle, the outer surface of which is covered with numerous longitudinal rough ridges. There are only four strongly-ribbed shell plates in the circle, although the strong surface texture makes the shell plates hard to count. Shell plates contain numerous air-filled pores (clearly seen if dead shells are viewed from below).

Global: Namibia, South Africa and possibly Mozambique. Records from the tropical Indo-Pacific may be misidentifications of T. rufotincta (see related species below).

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.

A dominant species in the mid intertidal zone of more temperate shores throughout the region, especially abundant in more sheltered situations. Often occurs together with the Eight-shell barnacle Octomeris angulosa, which tends to replace it in more wave-exposed situations on the same shores. Newly settled larvae grow to a diameter of about 7-8 mm in the first year, declining to 4 mm a year by the third year of life. Average longevity is about 3 years.

Active feeders, sweeping their feeding appendages thought the water to filter out food particles, which may include planktonic organisms and particles of algae or other organic material. Larvae have been recorded feeding on mussel eggs.
Reproductive season extends for about 5 months with mature larvae most common from Nov-Feb and peak settlement of larvae form Jan- March.

Unlikely to be confused with any other intertidal barnacle in the Cape region, but progressively replaced by the similar but more tropical and pink-coloured Rosy volcano barnacle T. rufotincta from the south coast of KwaZulu-Natal northwards.

Boland, JM (1997). The horizontal zonation of two species of intertidal barnacle in South Africa. South African Journal of Marine Science, 18(1), 49–61.

Dye, AH (1992). Recruitment dynamics and growth of the barnacle Tetraclita serrata on the east coast of southern Africa. Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science, 35(2), 167–177.

Griffiths, RJI (1979). The reproductive season and larval development of the barnacle Tetraclita serrata Darwin. Transactions of the Royal Society of South Africa, 44(1), 97–111.
